awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Orchestration of Multiple Robotic Subsystems into a Commercially Viable Robotic Strawberry Harvesting System
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project includes development of berry post-picking screening and handling that will provide a safe and efficient way to remove contaminated berries from the processing stream of an automated harvester. The project will advance machine vision technology for robotic harvesting and will be a key enabling technology leading to acceptance of automated harvesting as safe and effective. The market sector addressed by this project is strawberry farmers, though the technology will be applicable to other types of fruit and vegetable farming as well. The automated harvesting technology advanced by this project will alleviate chronic and worsening labor shortages faced by strawberry farmers and will ensure that strawberries remain affordable and available to consumers. Filling the need created by farming labor shortages is a $1 billion business opportunity.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop new vision processing and inspection methods vital to enabling use of an automated, robotic strawberry harvester. Acceptance of automated harvesting technology by strawberry farmers hinges on the ability of the harvester to remove bad berries from the plant without allowing the undesirable berries from entering the harvester packaging stream and potentially contaminating large quantities of berries. To achieve this, it will be necessary for the harvester to identify and eliminate diseased, rotten, damaged, or infested berries at multiple stages in the stream from automated picking to final packaging. The classification method that identifies the berries to be eliminated will be extremely accurate, with a very high detection rate and a low false alarm rate. The methods developed will be suitable for installation on a farming machine that is subject to a harsh outdoor environment as well as the shock and vibration environment found on a robotic harvesting device. New handling processes will be developed that will allow automated inspection of the entire berry without damaging the fruit or creating a risk of cross contamination from infected berries, significantly advancing the state of the art for automated strawberry processing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Harvest CROO Robotics (HCR) has developed a commercial deployment roadmap based on NSF research toward our goals of optimizing harvesting rates with adaptive harvesting and providing value-added services for yield forecasting and plant health monitoring, utilizing the NSF Phase IIb funds. Autonomous harvesting of mature strawberries is the core objective of HCR, generating a significant amount of data. Various algorithms and strategies were experimented using statistical, machine learning, and deep learning techniques on the generated data to offer more valuable services to growers and opening new potential revenue streams for HCR. Extended data collection and feasibility for adaptation is being explored.

An updated version of the adaptive harvesting strategy was tested in the field during the Florida 2022-2023 harvesting season. The adaptive algorithm responded well to the rapidly changing crop conditions, slowing the harvester to a ground speed of 0.25 inches per second during a heavy surge of berry density to allow for picking over 10 berries per plant, and increasing to 7 inches per second in sparse production areas. The adaptive harvesting system is designed to work in conjunction with the yield estimation system to dynamically determine the pick schedule in the coming years.

A more comprehensive dataset on berry maturity has been gathered during the 2021-2022 season through a manual field audit, which was used to develop an initial regression-based formula for yield prediction with four different maturity stages (flower, large white, partially ripe, and fully ripe berries). The predictive power of the regression formula performs better under normal conditions but has challenges when the plants come under stress from adverse weather events and disease outbreaks. A neural network model was trained to analyze the images captured by each robot to detect each of those berry maturity stages, which could later be used in conjunction with the regression formula to forecast berry yield for the next pick cycle. The neural network model shows strong performance in detecting flowers and ripe berries but is in constant refinement for the intermediate stages to gain more repeatability in forecasting based on their state.

The harvester database has been upgraded to receive messages from the berry post-harvest inspection system explicitly declaring when it determines that a berry is diseased. The database can also store the image of the diseased berry. In addition, another neural network model was developed to detect anomalies in the berry plant by analyzing the images captured during the harvesting process.

The regression model and the neural network models to determine berry maturity stages and leaf anomalies will be continuously improved using data gathered from multi-year, multi-cultivar, and multi-field trials. We have planned to continue this data collection for 2023-2024 Florida Season on multiple farms to improve these models. The developed technology will further be improved and adopted in coming years.

A preliminary data collection was conducted using a single robot in California to gather information on local varietals and field configurations distinct from those in Florida farms. The trial results were utilized to design the B8 robot, specifically capable of accommodating unique planting bed configurations in both California and Florida. The designed robot has undergone testing in Florida, and plans include extended commercial operations on two different farms in the region during the 2023-2024 season.

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2023
Modified by: Robert Pitzer

Image
  • New harvester B8 punching rows for upcoming commercial trials in Florida farm.
